body: I noticed that the logs have more junk than usual, not related to this, more about spring. like ignoring our banner override in tests. I'll look into this stuff afterwards.
thanks. will be in next release
If this is obviated by #3617, please close it out. Thanks!
can you verify the master build addresses this CVE and also mention how you are validating CVEs?

We use a service called Snyk to verify vulnerabilities.

We detected this when verifying with Snyk against the bundled spring boot and zipkin.
We checked the contents of the zipkin jar and found that it was a CVE-unsupported version.
draft until green
ok thanks. are you able to test the current 2.24.4-SNAPSHOT (master) version prior to release?
@debraj-manna our next patch release will include 1.1.10.5 (already in master now). What approach are you using to vulnerability scans?
I will pick at this over the next couple days, as it takes over an hour to run through the benchmarks ;) https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3619

I saw the PR for the version update. Thanks.

I also confirmed that the version of the library contained in the jar created by building the master locally is updated.
Also, the snapshot version of the jar cleared the snyk check.
@codefromthecrypt We use [AWS Inspector](https://aws.amazon.com/inspector/).
thanks for the help and attention! we'll release a patch tomorrow.

I've been AWOL for over three years, but I'm back for a bit and will help craft a SECURITY.md. Especially, we need to re-engage site owners into maintenance positions, so that these are actually looked at.

Also, clarify that by release policy all dependency versions are updated or documented why not before any and every release. I noticed a lot of "whack a mole" library bumps as well maintenance of indirects instead of fixing the direct. This are could be clarified both in expectations and how to keep the advisories thing free of library bumps and focused on practice and code in this repo.

my 2p

here's an example of the odd versioning https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/releases/tag/zipkin-0.7.0 we release 0.3.0 then 0.7.0. The independent versioning is a cure worse than the disease, and makes sure things are not up to date unless someone remembers to make a strange version.

even stranger, this makes tags called "zipkin-0.3.0" which are the tags to the helm chart.. on a repo named zipkin. This is very confusing as no one would know this is about helm.

I'll try to budget time to redo this, if I have time. but basically we should stop polluting our tag space with confusing things.

Hi there, thanks for showing up on this. Helm was a complete community
effort driven by actual users and I also spent some time trying to automate
helm releases that is why you might find some missing releases because they
were mistaken. You can check also the PRs to see how all this happened.

Specifically talking about the tag "weirdness" you point out, an app and a
helm-chart are two different artifacts. Helm chart can change without the
actual app being changed and it felt overkill to do a zipkin release just
because helm changed. We also explored other alternatives like incremental
suffix but helm does not like other than a.b.c.

That said, we intentionally did 0.* on helm because it was still
experimental.

Zipkin 2.25 will target ES 8 per https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/releases/tag/2.24.4 We have some work to do next week including sourcing an image
thanks for keeping an eye out, @anuraaga!

thanks for the context @jcchavezs. this still should be fixed as the version race will continue to confuse things. It is probably best to move this to a different repository if true you can only use a tag that can eventually be mistaken for a real zipkin version. I'll ask some other folks.

for context, we have been using same version of zipkin and docker since forever, even though there are times when docker has a change even when zipkin doesn't. That's an established precedent and while imperfect has resulted in both not missing docker releases, but also we have the ability to re-release docker (e.g. via the docker-x.x.x tag).

In a project like this, we have to favor existing release process and coherence, or move something that doesn't match to a different repo.
new README test that the docker build works and the corresponding healthcheck, too, passed:

manually verified also, since there are a lot of lines.

```bash
$ ag 'import .*junit.' --java --noheading |grep -v '^\s*$' | wc -l

$ ag 'import .*junit.' --java --noheading |egrep -v '(^\s*$|junit5|jupiter)'
zipkin-collector/activemq/src/test/java/zipkin2/collector/activemq/ITActiveMQCollector.java:27:import org.apache.activemq.junit.EmbeddedActiveMQBroker;
```

There's also some common static analysis issues that [could be cleaned up](https://app.moderne.io/results/pCNYt89e6/details/eyJfX3R5cGVuYW1lIjoiR2l0SHViUmVwb3NpdG9yeSIsIm9yaWdpbiI6ImdpdGh1Yi5jb20iLCJwYXRoIjoib3BlbnppcGtpbi96aXBraW4iLCJicmFuY2giOiJtYXN0ZXIifQ==?referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fapp.moderne.io%2Fresults%2FpCNYt89e6), but I was doubting if that's appreciated as it does switch some stylistic choices perhaps.

And of course if you'd want to run any of these same recipes against other openzipkin repositories I can facilitate that through the platform; just let me know and I can setup an OpenZipkin organization to select there.

@timtebeek wrt OpenZipkin organization. Thanks, it would be helpful. Once we release 2.25.0 here we'll go to zipkin-reporter-java and do the same things notably off junit 4. Moderne is already proving a good decrufting tool, particularly as we are free to use offline and leave no side effects in the build.
rebased
kicked the JDK 11 build. I'm not sure what it hung on, but it spent 10 minutes with no feedback in the zipkin-server module. This isn't a repeating flake pattern so far..
thanks for the support for the last week plus @anuraaga!
one pass and kicked

Ah perfect, you can now select OpenZipkin from top left corner and run recipes against all of these repositories
![image](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/assets/1027334/c3d70a64-7b11-4461-bf77-180612094eac)


Here's first run of JUnit Jupiter best practices against among others the zipkin-reporter-java that you mentioned:
https://app.moderne.io/results/YiPSV5epL

You can then follow up with the AssertJ best practices, Logging best practices and any other recipes you feel might improve the code there. Hope that helps!
I checked in zipkin-reporter that this works even with okhttp 3.14.9 in the classpath.

closing this out as the root cause was an unnecessary dep. The benefit of this is that it excludes the junit:junit dep. After a close look while okhttp isn't releasing as often as before, it is being worked on in the main branch, so not a big deal to keep as is.

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-reporter-java/pull/221 shows it works as is in the reporter, and I don't expect any issues with zipkin-finagle that also uses it in our org.

helidon which is the other main consumer doesn't appear to have a conflict and we can re-open this if that's unresolvable. I can see in their code they are already working around okhttp kotlin stuff, so they may be ok resolving it, and if not we can re-open this.
first run resulted in commits that wrote files with 2022, based on history, but since it is 2023 now I think a second run was needed as the commit itself touched the files. ðŸ¤ž this works now

@timtebeek is there a way to have the default template suggest the maven command to achieve the same? I think the login is nice, but it isn't good for having history of how this was done in the projects issues and/or commit log.
4x green in a row isn't a guarantee, but it is hope!
thanks for the progress @tacigar!
as yoda once said.. At this thanks for looking, rag.

> @timtebeek is there a way to have the default template suggest the maven command to achieve the same? I think the login is nice, but it isn't good for having history of how this was done in the projects issues and/or commit log.

Hmm I agree with you there, but I don't know if this is easy to change in the platform; we support Maven, Gradle, Bazel and other tools, and the instructions would have to differ based on what was used in the project. I've thought of linking to docs.openrewrite.org, but that then just shows an URL quite similar to the app.moderne.io link for this one: https://docs.openrewrite.org/recipes/maven/cleanup/prefixlessexpressions
And while that page does contain instructions for a rerun, I don't think such a link would add very much more details in this particular case that are not available from the Moderne link. Perhaps it would help if we allow access to recipe pages without a login such that the details are immediately visible; that's come up before, but gets tricky with authentication. No perfect solution I guess. :)

I did notice you ran this one recipe, but we also have a few more Apache Maven best practices documented here: https://docs.openrewrite.org/recipes/maven/bestpractices

Here's a quick run that reorders pom elements and adds missing groupIds and plugin versions: https://app.moderne.io/results/ssUD0Xzgq
ok fire in the hole `git push origin release-2.25.1`
sounds very sensible

for now you can try the quick start https://zipkin.io/pages/quickstart.html

```bash
$ curl -sSL https://zipkin.io/quickstart.sh | bash -s
$ java -jar zipkin.jar
```

One question for the home-brew thing, is if this should be the full zipkin build (includes kafka etc) or slim (smaller and a bit quicker to startup, but no messaging support)

The main issue is "Scylla does not support SASI" which is how a lot of indexing works. So, we could make ScyllaDB work quickly if search is disabled.. then, we can think about how to address non-SASI to make it work fully. Does this seem like an incremental way out?

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-storage/cassandra#trace-indexing

Another issue I recall from the past was having a test image to make sure what we think works works.. I assume we can make a docker image similar to https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/docker/test-images/zipkin-cassandra without violating any license with them. If we can't host a docker image it is unlikely we can promise things besides "best efforts"

hmm at some point, we had support for very large traces (1000s of spans). perhaps there are a lot of tags in your spans? Is there a way for you to share a file that scrubs personal data to test with? https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-lens/testdata

I think if we want to support open search, we need a docker image for it. similar to https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/docker/test-images/zipkin-elasticsearch7

Are you able to help create this? If not, let us know.
I have given up on zipkin and switched to sentry

I opened https://gitlab.alpinelinux.org/alpine/aports/-/issues/15582 in alpine just in case there's something they can look into.

Meanwhile,  @openzipkin/armeria is there a way to disable tcnative via flag? Also, if anyone has a chance to help with this, it would be appreciated. I fear if we can't resolve this we will need to remove boringssl as M1 Mac is a primary use case.
@rogierslag @DevLomoSE meanwhile, you can switch to the zipkin-slim image which excludes boringssl. As long as you aren't using messaging you can use this instead.

@codefromthecrypt I believe you can set `useOpenSsl` flag to false to disable tcnative and it uses JDK for TLS instead

https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/main/core/src/main/java/com/linecorp/armeria/common/Flags.java#L547
I noticed that the version of netty-tcnative-boringssl-static brought in by armeria is one patch behind... testing locally for luck
upgrading seems to work, I'll raise a PR
netty has a PR on this, but it looks like the build is broke https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/13724 cc @trustin in case you can help put some ðŸ”¥ under it!

I think this is a continuation of #1827 as that issue wasn't closed. This needs analysis still. There are other transports and storage that can leverage alternate keystore etc, so best to use a coherent approach to this.
Curious.. is this about the in-memory (test) configuration of zipkin, or using a particular storage option.
there are zero CVEs anymore except in the UI (lens), which is being addressed.

master no longer crashes, so the next patch out today will fix it in a formal release

```bash
$ docker run --rm -e "STORAGE_TYPE=elasticsearch" -e "ES_HOSTS=http://es.dev:9200" -e "ES_INDEX=zipkin" ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin:master
```
latest version of zipkin has all netty CVEs addressed
fixed sometime between then and now
Sorry no one looked into this, but I just verified this works with latest.
JDK 11 build hung twice in a row now. Since that's the release build, I'll dig further on it.
first step is making our ES 7 image use the Elastic licensed distribution. I am working on this.
maybe it is javadoc related, as that uses a lot of memory. I stopped running that in the test build.
Thanks for the watchful eye @anuraaga!

Kafka is already available in [homebrew](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/f49bf3578641d7bd93021553c7ecf99255b137e7/Formula/k/kafka.rb), maybe the other components in the full zipkin build are also present.

I guess you could have a jar that contains only zipkin code and either include a dependency on kafka explicitly (and the other dependencies) or having something without kafka support included but that could find it opportunistically if present.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/releases/tag/2.25.2

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/releases/tag/2.25.2 cites the docs I revamped in the examples, to show literally the command to use when not waiting for the hourly cron to finish. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/docker/examples/README.md#elasticsearch

Any more questions, please follow-up on [gitter](https://app.gitter.im/#/room/#openzipkin_zipkin:gitter.im), thanks!

Brave doesn't use this, but in brave, using mockwebserver3 creates an irresolvable classpath conflict on below:

```
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: 'void okhttp3.internal.concurrent.TaskRunner.<init>(okhttp3.internal.concurrent.TaskRunner$Backend, java.util.logging.Logger, int, kotlin.jvm.internal.DefaultConstructorMarker)'
```

This should be reverted because the cure is worse than the disease (junit:junit dep which is already present in most apps). We can revisit when okhttp releases again
rebased and added comment
Thanks @anuraaga !!

Next step for this is to make a new elasticsearch8 image. The core infrastructure is the same as this https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3636 except the image will be more like elasticsearch7. It won't be exactly because not only has the download URL changed, but also there is only a JDK version (you can skip the jdk directory to use our JRE). once a PR like this is merged, someone with commit access needs to go to that package and mark it as public so it is downloadable.

After that happens "ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin-elasticsearch8:master" should work and progress on the actual driver can resume.

added next steps to #3468 as I am on holiday for a bit I cannot finish this now. I ended up needing a lot of time to address lack of maintenance on all projects including brave. In any case, this issue is a dupe

please see notes at the bottom of #3468 about the base docker image, which is needed before this can proceed. If someone has time, please work on it in the next couple weeks, as the base project is totally ready for maintenance and change again.
thanks for the look!
